interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

div.title: Turas.
div.p:
Chuir an athair a thriuir mhac
eir falbh le ealaich agus thug
e earail orra gun meall a thoirt
as an ealealaich agu ach gun dad
a thoirt aiste. D Chuir e ceann
turais rompa s cha rorobh i ri
fhaicinn gu de bha iad a giulan gus
an ruigeadh iad an ceanceann uidhe.
Dh folbhDh fholbh an triuir bhrathaireain
agus eir an astar smaoinsmaoinich
am brathbrathair bu shinneshine gur h-Ã¨
an ceann am meall a bha
athair a ciallachadh agus
thug e cheann as an ealealaich as
thuit e. Bha dha bhrathair eile
a spuirst fhanaid eir agus
ghaghabh iad eir agharstadhart. Nuair a
thill e dh-innis e gu athair na
smaoinsmaoinich a chinnich aige.
Ni thu feum fhastfhathast arsarsa athair
dhiomhairich thu mo run.

div.title: Turas eile
div.p:
Chuir an athair a thriuir
mhac eir falbh agus thug e

a falbh agus a chuile h-allt no

div.p:
Coinneach Odhar. is said to have
been born at Howbeag â the son of a
widow. He dreamt & got up & dug the
sand on the strand. Twas thotthought that he got
derg. He wrotwrought hard at this for a long time.
He then got a box & in the box a stone
& in the stone all the prophecy â buaibuaidh
He kept the stone & as long as he kept
it he prophngprophesying. He threw frfrom himhimself the stone
in a lake at near Lochness. When
this lake is draindrained the stone will be
found & then many things will cmcome
to light. He heard a voice when
he was lifting the box on the strand
Prophecies â Uist (NNorth) will be fo
gheoigheoidh ghlas us caorcaoraich gheala which
is true. A battle will be fotfought at Clad
achCladdach & the fieachfitheach will drink his fill
of the blood of the slain on the top
of Clachamhor a che. Passg.Passing
a lake at Oban-cui - lianacleit
he said that Lake (Dig mhor
would yet be the best croce feamfeamad
in Uist. There he prophprophesied about
the Macneills of Barra & the duinduine
mor 24 meoir, & maor nan ordagan
mora a sgrisgriobhadh leis an lailaimh chearr
This maor went to Barra to sequester
MacnillMacneill. He said a coit bheag
would yet carry all the Macdonalds
in S.South Uist when the whole country
was full of these.

Calum BÅdach in N.North Uist had
taisearactaibhsearachd& confirmed many of CCoinneach Odhars.
The man repreaped ClaiClaidh Chorcail & then
threw at IocarIochdarI the sheaf of corn at the cow
which began eatgeating & he left & the owner
of the sick cow was dingdying. CCoinneach Odhar
is the seer mentmeant in S.Saint Clair of
the Isles.

The milk was boilgboiling on the fire & evyevery
bubble that got up a pin was stuck in it
& a handful of the thatch upon the lintel
of the house of door of those who were susp-
ected of taking away the torradh was
burnt in dirdirection of the milk. To bring

His son was a sore tyrant & DonlDomhnull

Coll.Colla Mac Speur built & was burned
in the chapel on 'Caibeal Cui-
Cros-Ã©. There was a 'Cui' here
the stones of whose wall Dr. Mac
Gillivray carried away for building
purposes. See Martin ppage 92.

The Rev. John Macaulay
was ministminister of S.South Uist. & settled there
in 18 1746 & left in 1756. Mr Mac
Grigor Lismore says that Macaulay
came to Lismore in 1746?
MacaulaysMacaulay was disliked in S.South Uist
& the people were glad when he left. One
Macleod who had been missionary
in Benbecula was the choice of the
people & Clanranald but Mr Aulay
& Macqueen MinistMinister of N.North Uist man
agedagreed to change the place of Presbytery
& thus got time put off till the prepresentation
lampsedlapsed to the PrebyPresbytery. The case
was brotbrought before the assembly but the PresPresbytery
managed to gain it their case
Macaulay then went to Lismore
where he was no better liked & where he
remdremained 10 yrsyears. Lord Macaulay's father
was probably born here. Macaulay
regretregretted leaving LisLismore & the last Sunday
he prechedpreached there he said to the congncongregation
that he was willing to remremain & that if any two
of them wldwould stand up & request him to rereconsider
he would still remremain. The But there was
no response. Macaulay was sucsucceeded by
Donald Macnicol a man whose
name is still honoured in LisLismore and
who is well known elsewhere as the authauthor
of an able critique upon Dr JohnsonJohnson's
Tour to the Hebrides.

sward & anothanother egg rolled against
it. The perperson who strikes his neighneighbour's
egg with his in rolingrolling it gains
the egg.

ish (Auish). Nioc a'ist

But he told. & he went to Lochbrac

She had an illegtillegimate son who lived in

Old Donald Macinnes 73 Buail

ceil orm ceil orm said she or

Many chambers & galleries round the dun.
A large eel still in this large-mane
as long as that of a horse. Eelt whistles
like a man. Seen oftoften & going in shallow
water from this to another lake.

Uamh AiriAiridh 'n t Sluic Lochsheile
vagh near Caolas Luirsey SSouth Uist
Monday 25 March 1872.
Took boat att Carnan
about 10 am with AchdArchibald
Macdonald the boat
man & four 3 workmen.

figure.figDesc: Sketch diagram of the cave with measurements

div.p:
Got to the AiriAiridh an t Sloic & set
to work in throwing out the mud
And such sticky gluey con
sistent mud I have never
seen. Found the head of the Uamh
& found also that we were at
it before although we did not
know it which is provoking now
that it might have saved all
this lost bother. The 'sloc' is a
hollow triangular hollow with
two lumpish hills on two sides
& a rising moor on the other. In
the hollow is a mound of stones
& earth full of limpet shells & oyster
shells probprobablytaken frfrom Loch sgiport
near by. In sum this mound
is overgrown with tall ferns (5 & 6 ftfeet)
The surface is covered with cro-nean
& cotain (cro cotan) (cro chaor-
ach (cotan 'laogh') & hence
the name "Airi."

The mud is within 1Â½ ftfeet of the top of the
gallery. Mud supsupposed to be 3 ftfeet deep.
The stones cross (supsupposedly as shown.
The 'house' runs along the up side
of the mound. The water oozing
down upon it is the cause of the
mud no doubt.

Taruin-mhor = Stocks
or Piollaid = PiollaryPillory

Cladh Choinnich in Fudey
from Caonneach Barrach
burying his oide & mimemuime there.

A poor man came frfrom Stony BenBenbecula

chadail. CÅtan a plplace for the

Uan. Cotan laogh for young
calves. MainirMainnir = Grass grown
ruins. The BaolBaoghalaich had only got up to
his airiairidh at dusk & the other left
so he thotthought to come when he was in
Glen Liadail. He & his boy made
a bed of fraoch & fianach in
the airiairidh theine. He began his urni uirnicuirnigh
& crabhach & saw 3 men big with
white chests brolbroillich. He set to pray
& struck his breast. One demdemanded him
to give up hiscrabhcrabhach & be off â that he
had no 'duches' to be there but that
shldshould be there Niall MacGilleaspuMacGilleasbuig
a Carnan Staonabrig. In terror
the man wakened his boy by his side
got his horse & off. He in turn
thotthought he would make an airiairidh at
Bealach rosgairt. So he set to &
built an airiairidh there but the same

John Macdiarmid Scalpay is a
son of Angus MacdoMacdonald ic DhonilDhomhnuill
ic FheargisFhearguis. His fathfather was Stew
ard to the Campbells of Strann.

The sons of the Duke of Argyle & of M
leodMacleod leod of DunDunvegan at GlasGlasgow collcollege â in collgecollege
in EdinEdinburgh. Macleod & a gille Sasunnach
challenged each for a fight in fists. The
Gille SasSasunnach was yet the best & John CampCampbell
who was young Macleod's second stepstepped
in his place & killed the Gille SasSasunnach. The
2 lads fled & cacame to DunDunvegan Young MMacleod told his
fathfather how CCampbell went is far so MacMacleod sent
his biorrlinbirlinn to Rodal & frfrom there
to Housinish & gave him HuisHuisinish &
Leosavagh Bunavinsui
Cleasamil Miavag
He built a house. Old Mac
leod put mar fhiachadh in
to marymarry & that he d get a wife for
him & he got this. He had 5 sonsons they
got Strannd tack & Kiligry 1-
Esey & Caolas Stead 1 ScalpyScalpay
& Caolas & 4 Larisg & the 5 reremained
with his fathfather John. The one
at Strann died & was sucsuceeded
by the one who reremained at HuisHuisinish with
his fathfather. The son of the one
who got Scalpay was apappointed petherpeithire

self as pether This office was
in the family for genergenerations & the
last by Iain og Mhar
aig The last of the Scalpay
family was an offofficer in the army
& got women throthrough drink & died in a
taitaigh suarach in Ile. He & his lady
burdburied in the side of his fafather at Scalpay.
His fafather was the last of the Scalpay famfamily

div.title: NieanNigheanan RiRigh.
div.p:
There was a King & he had 3 sons. His wife
died & he marmarried again & he had only
one datdaughter. The Le-chlach-ulairLe-chlach-urlair told the
Kings wife that the King had no love
for her datdaughter but only for his 3 sons. A bhean
dhona gholach bharacbharrachd eir a
bhean shona shÅlach bh agam
roiroimhe so gu de tha mise deandeanamh ort
tha mise u gle dhiar orm ach tha
ort fhein â Cha mhumhutha eir as mi
do t aon do niennighean seach piseag chat
seach a 3 mac fhein How can
I help that â send them to ask the
â cir mhin orms. which she did
The eldeldest camcame first Chuir mo mhu
orm shin na cir mhin O
mhic mna mo ghaoil m
fhaoilte s m' onarach mar
a bhi fior nam ghluin bior nam
shuil s fior nam ordaig dh-
eirinn a ghaoil s bheir pog
dhuit. Chan urainurrainn mise
sin thoirt duit. Ach theirig usathusa
suas thun na ciste ud shuas
& thoirt leat i. When he bent
over the cist for the cir She
rose & struck him with the slat
an druieacdruicheachd & thereupon he flew
up the farlos to the house top a
fitheadh gearr dughdubh. Then the
2 sonsons came & asked for this brobrother
gorm shuileach donn a thainig
an de shinshineadh na cir mhin
ga mhuime. Mhic mna
mo ghaoil &c & so on the next.
Then the datdaughter demanddemanded of the
LeLe-chlach-urlair for her brobrother. TheThereupon he scoldscolded her
& toll she had not seen them.
She then & said to her momother
Ill make you that if my fathfather
is with son you shall be
with a dat.daughter & she left. She travtravelled
gus naan rorobh dudubh eir a bonbonn & toltoll air a
gruaidh gach ian buibuidhe bachal-
ach cearna bhuid doich-
uileach gailgabhail tamh am bun
nam preas sam barr nan
dos sam bun gach craoicraoibh is
cruine calltain b fhaisge
dhen radrathad mhor na chuil
bhinn i sin taitaigh mor eir
urlar glinne s gad b fhad
uaiuaith i cha b fhad i gan
ruthinruithinn. GhaGhabh i staistaigh & cha rorobh
eir ach smudan beag tein
& gun duine stistaigh ach cat
maol donn dudubh sa dhronchroit
ri teallach. ShuiShuidh i ri taotaobh
na griosaich & leum an cat na
h-uch-uchd Bha i ga liobadh & gun
mhineadh & bha easeasan ri cron
an s ri seinn. Nam bu bhean
mi & nach bean mi rud nach
eil & nach rorobh & nach bi. Dh-
fhosglair am preas ud fhein
& bheir as am biabiadh a smaoinsmaoineachadh
eir & am biabiadh nach smaoinsmaoineachadh
& deoch na &c c & ghaghabh mi
fhein mo leoir dheth & nam
borrainburrain fhein bheir part dhe
dhan chat mhaol dudubh bhios
an oir na lualuaidh s mar tog
leigin leis bhuaillin uam e.
She did this & gave her share
to the cat. She took out the food
thought of & the food unthought
of & so of the drink. She placed
the cat on the end of the table & shared the food
with him. Nam bu bhean mi s gun
bu bhean mi rud nach eil nach eile nach
rorobh &c chuir uisge blabalth eir mo
chas & nan tog chuir diar beag
biteach eir casan a chait mhaol
dhuidhuibh onbiosbhios oir an teine She s mar
tog gha'ainghabhainn iolla ris. She did
& she pladplaced him at her feet in
bed. & he was a crooning. When
she awoke in the mornmorning the cat was
gone. She was lamentlamenting. She saw
6 skulls on a stuip & one stop with
out a skull. She walked out & she
met the oganach buibuidhe donn
who asks her sgial & fafath a turais
dhan ghleann. She told who & whwhat
was all her troubles. No perperson ever came
to the Glen said he but sacrificed his
life for his temerity. The cat killed them
& these are their heads upon the 7th
sto stuip. The 7th stop if for you =
If that be my fate said she I must
abide it But I am in great grief
for the black cat & I am lonely in
the house without it I wish had
returned. The oganoganach buibuidhe dhonn
left her â thug e siorradh a null
& siorradh a nall â & immed.immediately then
aftafter the black cat app.appeared She left
him in her bosom & he began
purgpurring &c They went home. He was
purg.purring on the knee & said Nam
bu bhean mi fhi & nach bean
mi &c dh fogdh fhosgladham preas ud thall
& bheir as am biabiadh & an dibh eir am
smaoinsmaoineachadh & am biabiadh& an dibh
eir nach do smaoinsmaointich mi & ghaghabh eir
mo bhiabhiadh 's mo dhibh & nan
tog fhefhein bheir part dhan chat
pheallach ghreannach dughdubh
an oir na luadh smar tog. Bheir
gleo'argleodhar a null s buile nall
dha s dhiandhianadh mar a thogthogras fhein
This was the others customs. She
did this & fed the cat. Then the water
same as before. On the 3 day the
og.oganach buidhe donn appappeared & told her he was
the cat & that he had been fo gheagheasaibh
& would ever be till he would a prin
cess â he being a prince â to do to him
as she had done althoalthough in riocriochd cait.
Then they marmarried & lived togethtogether happhappily
ever after & she never rereturned to her discon
solate gmothergrandmother

div.title: EllenEilean Gaineacha
div.p:
A man coming fr.from abroabroad & he saw
a black bad omomenspot & he nearneared & what was
this but & iallain an t saoilt saoghail&
fgfinding above a small islisle. He put out
the punt A large ford ran
across the islisle & a stac of fish
bones on the eaeast side of the ford. He deldeliberated
that he shdshould have some for dindinner in
such a plplace He left with the intintent
of retgreturing He came to EnglEngland Ere
he could retreturn went came in &c
knowknowing the wildwildness of the plplace with
out anchorage exexcept the ford
He & othsothers retreturned & when thythey came
no islisle was visvisible. They were mock
ing him & they began sounding &
found nothing but rock
& this they called Rockall.
Remarks Remarks
Ferguson has left Greintote & gone to Rudale

Donald McLennan has Suceeded him & has two Dogs which
I saw = he says Mr McDonald Rudale pays them

Donald Stewart was away at Kelp but I assertainedascertained he has a
Dog "DonDonald Boyd has one Dog Saw his wife who Said that
They had no money to pay for the Dog at present

Saw Murdoch Ross son who Said he would go to
Lochmaddy on Tuesday first & pay the Dog

he will See his master first
ArchArchibald McLean has a Dog at Bailimartin

div.title: Rocabarrai
div.p:
DunDuncan Maclellan Mason
Carnan 27 26 AplApril 1872

A man came to Barra
& none kneknew frfrom whence he was
& had 3 sons. He fishfished & othother boats
went also but he went farther
& althoalthough the others retreturned empty he nevnever
retreturned but loaded. The others were
envyenvious of this. He was now
& an old man He then said
to his sons I am now going Transcribed No 4 Book 27 AprApril1872
AAlexanderAArchibaldCCarmichael
home & you better come with meme to
B. RocabarRocabarra. What sort of
plplace is that. A charmed isle
(Siannta) & all see nothnothing
but sea over it but the isle
is quite dry notwithingnotwithstanding. Come
uyou wtwith me & live the while you
live. No. Well, whethwether you are
or not I am bound to return
& I wdwould wish you to follow
me. The sons wdwould not go but
they fished as ususual. One day he
said we ought to go fishfishing today
lads CounCount evyevery barralbarrel hddhogshead & tail
& put them in the boat. Done
they proproceeded to leave. Other fishfishermen
said Nach ceachara dhuinn fhifhin
We must folfollow till we see wrewhere
they get the fish & they folfollowed. They
He went out far in the cuan
Now I am leaving uyou & there is
aon iolliolla so & I d like to teateach
it to you ere we part. It never
failfailed me. We are now near
it. The name of the illo
to Iolla nam muca-mara

TheyThe other skiffs race & fish round

deaf blind. ProceeProceed on till you

Look out said he to his sons
if you see anything comh-
raichte feadh a chuain.
No, nothnothing. Tis time to leave. No

is so plentplentifuil. It wdwould not be my
adviadvice to you he said Look again
& look well mor thimicheall.
No nothgnothing â Time to leave. This
is Illo na muc mara &
this is LathawouldLa cheann na blia
nnabliadhna & tis today muca mamara
come to cladh & cleasaccleasachd &
if we are before them pity us.
othother Tis hard to see said one
son but Ill look yet & Ill
stand up. I see like a break
eir break over a rocrock. None
there ever was a bogha. he
but the ball â wait not to lift
the cruaicruaidh said the old man
these are the whales. They set to
before the wind with canvas set
Ere they got away the whales were
close at hand in 100s. What
has become of the bodach said
all the other Barra boats. He
surely has not filfilled his boat at
not his charmed luck.
The bod.bodach waved to the othother boats to run
awyaway but they only laughlaughed. They
saw the whales & they proproceeded to be
but ere they got away & pigs
got among them & they broke &
drowned the other 3 sgothsgothan & none
of these were ever seen again.
Many of the pigs folfollowed the bodbodach
in their mad fury. TheyThe bodbodach
was contcontinually askasking how the pigs
were doing & the sons tellgtelling him
I fear the fate of the others
will fall upon us seeing you wdwould not folfollow my advadvice.

The pigs were close astern.
They had 7 hhdshogheads. 1 they threw out
to the pigs. The pigs played with
this they brokbroke it & sonso on They were runrunning
near shore & threw out the last.
They got ashore eir eigin
& none but the bodach & his
3 sons got ashore alive.

On the morrow he
said now lads you must
send me home. I have now
taught you aon iolla iasg
a chuain Mark lalatha checheann
na bliannabliadhna & that is the only
day you have to fear. Mark
also the signs I taught uyou
send me home now this day
so come away. They sat over
to the ocean. Steer W.West S.South W.West & keep
open the bealach ann an
Beinn bhearnach BharaiBharraidh.
They proproceeded till they were imimmensely far
out. One son said How fool.foolish
we are goiggoing to cuan mor
na h-airde niar where
land is never seen Had we
not better retreturn You have
not narnear the plplace yet. They
proproceeded on & anothanother said how
foolfoolish No not yet. Again
the bodbodach said I shdshould think we
are not far frfrom the home of
my youth now. Nothing seen
here but the cuan mor said

div.p:
Oran bean thuiream. In any township there was a bean
tuiream, like a bean ghluin,
whose duty it was to sing the tuiream
after the coffin & striking the
coffin with her hands like a drum.
All the man's virtues were sung
out & his geanaology back to Noah
praised.

His his datdaughter where lay their strength.
The onaid told him that they had

day but none at all at night.
So Macneil set to work fell upon
them at night & kilkilled them all.
His datdaughter was torrach & bore
a son who was called

div.p:
Carra on Dun a Charra
was thrown by a L.lanLochlannach while in the
traitraigh buain bhairbhairneach. He had
this as an ord bhan. He threw
this at his leannan & kilkilled
her for he was jealous of her.
He struck & kilkilled her sunk
her in the earth. The carra stands
there â another lying by its side

Mac an Amhuris was an il
gitimate son of MacnilMacneil His

to Fuidey. Nam bu mhamhath
dhomh thu bhi tu dha
do phiuphiuthair Land mi in FuidFuidey
said Mac an AmhAmhuris DonDonald
DuDubh set at them S mise mac
an AmhAmhuris a rugadh do Mhic
Neill s mar bi mi agaibhse
bi mi agam fhefhein He kilkilled
them all. He was at the lann-
aig the folfollowing mornmorning with his sistsister
on hand 'S fhiurfhearr sin said

Chailein. The remains
of these men are turnturned up now

& the sons went to Cape Bre
ton. Brass dore lake & took
the cumcumain where they boutbought
lands with them.

div.p:
25 Sep.September LaLatha Fheill Barra horse
racing in Barra at Cille Bharra
& 29 SepSeptember St Micheil horse racgracing
at Borve. Going 3 times round
the cladh. A man had always
a woman behind him on the
horse. Every girl after mass mass
on Sunday went to dig up wild
carrots & every girl of subt.substance had a
lindealach lassie gathering
wild carrots. The girl had a white
plaiding with red stripes with each
pocket on each side full of these
carrotcarrots. Their dress was tucked
up. They used to make the cloth
very fine. A web could be drawn
through a finger ring. The more
culags a girl got. Then they all
retreturned to a place & had a ball. EvyEvery
principal hohouse had a party.
& ball.

Mac De & the Donas were competing
in leapleaping â the DonDonas defy.defying the Lord who
should leap farthest. The Lord's mark
is farthest & so he won the vicyvictory. Tobar
na buaibuaidh is under the ala and the
footmark out from it hence the name.
The D.Donas footmark is splayed & ugly
& the other is shapely & attractive.

div.l:
The Pearsan Mor was chaplin
& son to Macneil. He had house at
Ciolla & mmarried to a datdaughter of Clanranald.
He used to go shooting to Aird Ghriun
when There was an athanother girl at Cliat
upon his wife thought he was fond of
her & she was g iadach rithe.
She sent for her 12 co attenattendants to visit &
they came. He was gone to Aird Ghriun
as usual. His wife told them where
he was gone & told them to wait him
at Ciste nan Cli'eann where they
would hear his dogs' coinneal (cham)
comgcoming throthrough the ciste. They met & attacked
him. He & his dog killed 10 out of the 12 &
the other 2 lived till morngmorning. He fotfought
them till he fell at Meallach whence
he was buried & a caibeal was built
over him.

This cumha was compcomposed by a
lady whose affianced was kilkilled
in riding home from being
married. He had a splndsplendid black
horse wild to a degree
and it was faisneacfaisneachd that the
black horse would kill him
That morngmorning the black horse was so restive
that he leapt off his back & struck
him with his pistol. He then
took a white horse & in setgsetting home
the white horse saw the dead
horse lying. He startstarted & the
young man riding gayly un
guarded lost his seat & his
feet getggetting entangentangled in the strirrips
he was dragged aftafter the horse
& kilkilled ere he could be rescued.
The bride was riding on before
& some turn in the road took him
out of her sight till he was
brotbrought home dead & thus taigh
an solais was turnturned into taitaigh
dolais.

A girl was herdgherding cows. One got

the cow & if she make urine cork

was done. Then a womwoman came home
& said o come & see my mothmother.
She is swolenswollen & likelikely to die. No yes
No yes, & she went 3 times. She
then extactextacted the womwoman who was likelikely
to die never to do the like again.
This she vowvowed the botbottle was uncorkuncorked
& she got well. & so did the cow when
ever the womwoman got ill. She brotbrought
the cows illness upon herself.

div.title: DoulDomhnull Gorm Sleibhteach

lg.l: Bha mi nan raoir an tu.tullach rereidh
'S tha mi mam thall fhein a nocnochd
'S fiach a mhonanan thu sa ghan
Chan eil a speirid nam chorp
Mar bhi na coilean giuaisgiuthais
'S fhada bu chumha mo choinnu
'S meirig a dh-fagdh-fhag na thiernathighearna
Fear nach dian dlighea eir oireacoighreachd

div.p:
DonlDonald Gorm & his 16 co altan
got up from the aisirie and
were coming to his son. The son
a bad man heard they were comgcoming
& he went to an old man. Go
home said the old man im
medimmediately & turned up to yryour chairs
up side down right round the
table place pine candles
instead of wax candcandles on round the
table & a dearnagan with
a hole throthrough the midmiddle & the
taotaobh cearcearr up. Do this or yuyour fathfather
& 16 coaltcoaltan will re.remain with you
till they eat you up & the
oirreacoighreachd with you. DonlDonald
Gorm & his 16 coaltcoaltan at
his back enterentered the room
He looked & tried to get a seat
but the chairs were all
turnturned up & he could not get
put his finger near a thing.
They turnturned away in disgust.

Borve to go to a tobar fior
uisg nach tra'adhtraghadh or to a
stream forming a march &
to take home water from that â
To go ere sun rise or sun

or woman to see Place
silver in the dish & sprinkle
this 3 times on the cow.

LaLatha nam Marbh, the
people used to put off yryour
shoes & stockings & go with diol

propitiation to GGod â for the
souls in purgatory. Not
now bare footed.

div.title: Torradh Crannachain
div.p:
A tailor was workgworking in a hohouse in Skye.
The peoppeople of the hohouse were at working
the peats & the bean an taigh was
up in the ceann uacrach ris
a' chrannachan. A neigh.neighbour womwoman
came in & said her fire went out & she
wantwanted fire & she took it. Leum an
tailear s rug eir eibhle o thilg e sa
chuman e s shin e aig obair. The
neighneighbour womwoman did this 3 times each time
saysaying her fire went out. The bean
an taitaigh came down O nach
mise tha eir mo narachnarachadh
gag obair eir muigh shuas
an a sin fad fin foin-
each an lalathaa sgaine mo
chridhe s nach urrain mi transcribed B.Book. III p.204

got her butter there. - the fire
the woman was carry.carring away

Calum Gobha was over
in Bearnary during the storm
of 3 OctOctober 1860. The peoppeople were in terror
thinking their last had come.
Ghaoil a Chaluim reachrach usathusa suas
& cradhcrath an t uisge coisrigte â
GheoGheobh uthu anns a chiste bhig e fhad
sa bhios sinesinne ga'ailgabhail an urnigurnaigh
The peoppeople were all at their
prayers & CalCalum went up & in searsearching
for the holy watwater he found a botbottle of whisky
He took a swig out of it & prepretended to
be sprinkgsprinkling it over the horse
peoppeople & cattle This he reprepeated & the
storm abateabated. In the morngmorning bean
DhouilDhomhuilll Iain (Macintire) went
to give a dram to CalCalum her hushusband & all
the peoppeople aftafter their fright. The holy
water was there & the whisky was
not. Cal.Calum had a sore head & un
able to rise.

div.title: Saothach Mhaoldonaich
div.l:
Fear ShanntraiShanntraigh used to fish with
a sioman round his waist. He had
one 2 skifsskiffs â he in one himself & a
crew in anothanother He saw the ves.vessel on
shore & went to her. He took the boat
loads of gold frfrom her. He left taitaigyh
an duin at Bagha an airm Castle
bay where he had a "white house" â not
slated. He bur.buried the 21 casks of gold
am fianuis nan 3 tra'ana in
Caolas VatVatersay. The gre'argreidhear & he was the
very perperson burgburying the cask of 14 gills
fillfilled up to half when on end. They
both died in a fever rather
suddenly. On his death bed
the greargreidhear told but the peoppeople failfailed
to get. He ad.advanced the valvalue of the proprofit to Mac
Neil of Barra - his nephew. When
he Macneil told the credcreditor threatthreatened
to take the proproperty (Barra) fr.from him
Fear ShanntraiShanntraigh told him
that he would place a bonn
oir oir ri oir frfrom Port an
Lodain to opp.opposite Fearay to
PorstPort nam Marbh at Na
h-Orradh. When Fear ShannShanntraigh
died at Caolas (Vat.Vatersay). He built
the ho taitaigh Eachain Bhig Castle
bay) the funeral processprocession was met
at Bac by two idiotic sisters
called Na Goinseguin â
they lived in an underground
house at Tangastal)

div.title: LLaoidh Amadain Mhoir
div.p:
Cause a King's son
was fo gheasaibh and re
la in Gleann a Chait-
xchaotaich. The King
offoffered much gold to any
who wldwould bring his son frfrom
the geasgeasaibh Many were going
but No perperson could do this
unless he stadstayed 3 nights in
the Glen & evyevery one was dead
the first night. Ga be chuir
fo na geasgeasaibh e chuir e mar
chumha eir gun reachreachadh
e an riocriochd gach creatuair
beo & gach crutha. Many
went but all was dying. At
last the AmadAmadan Mor went
& sucsuceeded because he was
true to his trust.

div.title: St Barr or Finbarr
div.head: First Bishop of Cork
div.p:
He is called by some St Barrus
or Barrocus. He lived in the sixth
age; was a native of Connaught
and institued a monastery or school
at Lough Eire . . . .

This was the origin of the City
of Cork which was built chiefly
on stakes in marshy little islands
formed by the River Lea. St Fin=
Barr's disciple, St Colman son of
Lenin founded the Episcopality
of Cloyne fo which he was
the first Bishop; he died 4th
NovNovember 604. St Nessan who
succeeded St Finbarr in his
school & built the town of Cork
was another of his disciplesâ¦.

Sir James Ware & Tanner take
Notice, that some with a M. M. copy
He was bishop of Caithness
in the King's library at London
scribe to St Finbarr a letter on
the cermonies of Baptism printed
among the works of Alanin, The name
under which the St was baptized
was Lachan The surname Finbad
or Barr the white was afterwards
given him, He was Bishop of
Cork seventeen years & died in
the mist of his friends at Cloyne
His body was buried in his own
Cathedral at Cork St Finbarr's
bane or hermitage was shown
in a monasatery which see to
have been began at Cork by
himself & stood to the west in
Cork
See his life in M.M. in Fricks College Dublin MM 31 Geradus Cambran & Colgan MM 25 SeptSeptember
